Introduction

Trachoma is a chronic keratoconjunctivitis caused by infection with Chlamydia trachomatis serovars A, B, and C.  It is the leading infectious cause of blindness worldwide and is particularly prevalent in resource-limited areas in Africa, Asia, the Middle East, and parts of Latin America.  It is spread from eye to eye by contact with objects (eg, fingers, fomites, flies) contaminated by infectious ocular or nasal secretions.

Pathogenesis



Trachoma results from repeated infection with C trachomatis serovars A-C, which triggers a chronic inflammatory response in the conjunctivae.  Over time, this inflammation leads to scarring, in-turned eyelashes (trichiasis), and corneal damage, which can result in blindness.



The pathogenesis of trachoma occurs in 2 main phases (

figure 1
):



  • Active infection (follicular and intense inflammation):  This phase is most common in children and characterized by follicular conjunctivitis, or white-yellow follicles on inflamed upper tarsal conjunctivae.  Patients may be asymptomatic, even with widespread inflammation.  If symptoms are present, they include mild eye redness, itching, and discharge.
  • Cicatricial disease:  Repeated episodes of infection with conjunctival inflammation lead to scarring of the tarsal conjunctivae.  This scarring causes entropion (inversion of the eyelid) and trichiasis (misdirected eyelashes that rub against the cornea), leading to corneal ulceration, neovascularization (pannus formation), corneal opacification, and ultimately blindness.  A horizontal linear scar on the superior tarsal conjunctiva (Arlt line) and depressed, scarred follicles at the limbus (Herbert pits) are specific findings in later stages.

Risk factors



  • Poor sanitation and hygiene.
  • Limited access to clean water.
  • Overcrowding and close contact with infected individuals.
  • Children age 1-9 (most affected group).
  • Presence of flies (particularly Musca sorbens).
  • Females (due to increased child-rearing responsibilities).

Clinical presentation

Early (active) disease



The active trachoma phase is characterized by follicular conjunctivitis, in which white-yellow follicles appear on inflamed upper tarsal conjunctivae.  Papillae may appear with the follicles as pinpoint red dots.  Papillae may enlarge and coalesce to give the conjunctiva a thickened and edematous appearance.  Even with significant inflammation, children may be asymptomatic.  If symptoms are present, they include:



  • Mild eye irritation or redness.
  • Eye itching.
  • Light sensitivity.
  • Mucopurulent discharge.

Late (cicatricial) disease



The late (cicatricial) stage of disease is characterized by:



  • Eyelid scarring (thick horizontal band near the eyelid margin [Arlt line]).
  • Entropion or inward rolling of the eyelashes (due to tarsal scarring).
  • Herbert pits:  Follicles from the tarsal conjunctivae may leave grossly visible shallow pits on the cornea in later stages of the disease.
  • Corneal inflammation:  Because of eyelash abrasions, corneal edema and ulceration may be seen.  Corneal pannus (inflammatory vascular tissue) develops over time with repeated eyelash abrasions, which ultimately leads to corneal opacification and loss of vision.

Differential diagnosis



  • Bacterial conjunctivitis:  Predominantly characterized by mucopurulent discharge that immediately reappears after wiping the eye.  Follicle formation is rare on the upper tarsal conjunctivae.
  • Viral conjunctivitis:  Characterized by eye redness and a gritty sensation.  Although follicles may be seen on the upper conjunctiva, trachoma is distinguished from C trachomatis with its rapid-onset, mucopurulent discharge, and recent upper respiratory infection.
  • Allergic conjunctivitis:  Distinguished based on the seasonal nature and concurrent atopy history (eg, eczema, hay fever, asthma).  It is the most common cause of red, irritated eyes.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis is primarily made clinically in areas where trachoma is endemic.  It is staged with the WHO simplified grading scale based on conjunctival examination.

Stages of trachoma (WHO simplified grading system)



The WHO system defines 5 stages of trachoma (

  • Stage TF (trachomatous inflammationâ€“follicular):  â‰¥5 lymphoid follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva.  This stage is typically self-limiting over weeks to months; however, reinfection is common and leads to advanced stages of disease.
  • Stage TI (trachomatous inflammationâ€“intense):  Inflammatory thickening due to coalescence of papillae.  This stage is diagnosed when edema and inflammation obscure >50% of the deep tarsal vessels of the upper eyelid.
  • Stage TS (trachomatous scarring):  Scarring on the tarsal conjunctivae.  Clinically, this is seen as a thick, white band of tissue near the eyelid margin.
  • Stage TT (trachomatous trichiasis):  â‰¥1 eyelash touching the globe or evidence of eyelash removal.  This is graded as minor (1-5 eyelashes contacting the globe) or major (â‰¥6 eyelashes contacting the globe).
  • Stage CO (corneal opacity):  visible corneal opacity over the pupil that impairs vision.  Once corneal opacification is reached, trachoma is irreversible.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies



The most sensitive and specific test is nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).  Other options include direct fluorescent antibody test, enzyme immunoassays, microscopy with Giemsa staining of conjunctival samples, and tissue culture.  However, laboratory evaluation is not typically used in the diagnosis because availability (cost, technical experience) is limited in areas where C trachomatis is endemic.



Imaging studies are not routinely performed in the diagnosis or management of trachoma.

Management



Trachoma management is guided by the WHO SAFE strategy, which includes the following:



  • Surgery:  Bilamellar tarsal rotation surgery is needed for patients with entropion and trichiasis.
  • Antibiotics:  Mass drug administration with azithromycin in a single annual dose is recommended in endemic communities.  Tetracycline eye ointment applied for 6 weeks is an alternate therapy; however, oral treatment is preferred because it reduces nasopharyngeal and community carriage.  The WHO recommends annual antibiotic administration for 3 years in communities when the TF stage prevalence is â‰¥10% in children age 1-9.
  • Facial cleanliness:  This strategy focuses on regular face washing to remove discharge and reduce transmission.
  • Environmental improvement:  Antibiotics alone can eliminate trachoma; therefore, a focus on environmental improvements is also necessary.  This is accomplished with improvement to clean water access, improved sanitation (latrine construction), and fly control (eg, waste disposal, pesticides).

Prognosis



With early intervention, especially in active disease, the prognosis is excellent with antibiotics.  However, untreated chronic infection and inflammation can lead to corneal scarring and opacification.  At this stage, trachoma is irreversible and vision loss is permanent.

Prevention



Prevention is focused on mass treatment programs in endemic areas, along with education to promote facial cleanliness and hygiene.  Environmental improvements that focus on improving access to clean water, sanitation, and reductions in fly breeding are critical for eradicating trachoma.  Surveillance following mass drug administration is also critical to monitor for reemergence in a community.

Summary



Trachoma is a preventable and treatable infectious cause of blindness caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars A-C.  It progresses through a well-defined spectrum of inflammation, scarring, and corneal damage.  Diagnosis is clinical and based on WHO grading.  The cornerstone of control is the WHO SAFE strategy, emphasizing surgery, antibiotics, hygiene, and environmental change.
